column1: Guided Walk: A Scalable Recommendation Algorithm for Complex Heterogeneous Social Networks
Online social networks have become predominant in recent years and have grown to encompass massive scales of data. In addition to data scale
column2: these networks can be heterogeneous and contain complex structures between different users
column3: between social entities and various interactions between users and social entities. This is especially true in enterprise social networks where hierarchies explicitly exist between employees as well.In such networks
column4: producing the best recommendations for each user is a very challenging problem for two main reasons. First
column5: the complex structures in the social network need to be properly mined and exploited by the algorithm. Second
column6: these networks contain millions or even billions of edges making the problem very difficult computationally.In this paper we present Guided Walk
column7: a supervised graph based algorithm that learns the significance of different network links for each user and then produces entity recommendations based on this learning phase. We compare the algorithm with a set of baseline algorithms using offline evaluation techniques as well as a user survey. The offline results show that the algorithm outperforms the next best algorithm by a factor of 3.6. The user survey further confirms that the recommendation are not only relevant but also rank high in terms of personal relevance for each user.To deal with large scale social networks
column8: the Guided Walk algorithm is formulated as a Pregel program which allows us to utilize the power of distributed parallel computing. This would allow horizontally scaling the algorithm for larger social networks by simply adding more compute nodes to the cluster.
